column13: Allow bounding box drawing around label
column21: I just pushed a fix for this in 8bb648f.  The text drawable for a LabelNode has culling explicitly disabled with setCullingActive(false).  I've disabled culling of the bounding box drawable in the same way and it appears to work correctly now.  The reason that culling needs to be disabled is b/c the drawables are eventually rendered using the screen space layout, so their world space bounding boxes aren't necessarily what is finally rendered.

column13: EarthManipulator terrain avoidance minimum distance setting added, no…
column20: … longer using minimum focal distance for terrain avoidance.
column21:
This resolves a specific scenario for us where we were receiving reports in our osgEarth-based app that terrain avoidance was not functioning.  It was not functioning because we use a negative "minimal focus distance" to allow for zooming through models.  We do this to support a feature called Cockpit mode and it works great.  Imagine being tethered to an aircraft model, following its yaw, pitch, and roll, zoomed forward so you're sitting on the nose.
But by setting a negative focus distance, it messes up the terrain avoidance minimum distance, which uses the same variable.  We've seen lots of funky behavior with terrain avoidance doing something "close to right" but not quite right.  I finally tracked it down to the reuse of this variable.  The only documentation that I could find that this variable was used was from Glenn on our internal help desk, who mentioned this on the same issue that this change resolves (SIM-4453).
In short, this lets us independently vary the minimum "zoom" value and keep it distinct from the "minimum distance from terrain" variable.  Though they're both minimums, they represent two different values both conceptually, and (in this patch) in the code as well.

column13: MapNode and EarthManipulator no longer crash when terrain driver (e.g…

…. engine_mp) is not found.
Was getting a crash when the MP driver was explicitly used in configurations when the engine_mp plug-in was not found (typically due to end user misconfiguration).  This resolves the hard crash by adding NULL checks.
column21:
Is this to prevent a crash when the osgdb_osgearth_engine_mp.dll is not accessible at all, like it's not in your path?

Right, osgdb_osgearth_engine_mp.dll is not accessible at all.  This can happen if the end user developing an app messed up on their paths, or during configuration, or during a bad deployment.  We develop an SDK that uses osgEarth as a baseline and we get a surprising number of issues from end user developers that boil down to bad paths and not being able to load OSG plug-ins because of this.

What would osgEarth do if it can't find the terrain engine at all?

The only thing I would expect (perhaps "hope for") is that it not crash.  Beyond that, I'd expect that it couldn't do anything useful.  Most of the code already looks quite well protected against this, there were only a small handful of places I was able to spot in a "normal" run where pointer validity wasn't checked.
In our SDK we try to detect this condition and print debugging info to the end user (e.g. osgDB::Registry::getLibraryFilePathList() search path and the MP DLL name).  When the user has a misconfigured path, what we're seeing is an error from osgEarth about MP, then a crash (due to unprotected NULL accesses).  This PR simply prevents the NULL crashes in the cases I spotted.

column13: Add fast RasterIO sampling path for generating heightfields with nearest neighbor
column20: Especially when using compressed TIFF heighmaps, the terrain performance suffers a lot from the many 1-pixel RasterIOs performed in getInterpolatedValue. This pull-request adds a fast path when using nearest neighbor interpolation, which reads the entire tile in one go via RasterIO. On my machine I easily get a factor 8 speedup with this path using a LZW compressed DTM.
column21: Especially when using compressed TIFF heighmaps, the terrain performance suffers a lot from the many 1-pixel RasterIOs performed in getInterpolatedValue. This pull-request adds a fast path when using nearest neighbor interpolation, which reads the entire tile in one go via RasterIO. On my machine I easily get a factor 8 speedup with this path using a LZW compressed DTM.

column13: Triton: Now cleaning up terrain callback properly, preventing crash w…
column20: …hen changing ocean models.
column21:
In our application, we let the user change the ocean model.  Swapping out from Triton leaves stale pointer in not-removed terrain callback.  This both removes the callback and protects the TritonDrawable in an observer_ptr.  This fixes stale memory access and prevents crashes.
Also added some safety to the _contextDirty buffered_object to prevent out-of-bounds access.

column13: GeoPositionNode can now be configured to ignore setMapNode.  Some ins…
column20: …tances require having a NULL map.
column21: …tances require having a NULL map.

column13: GeoPositionNode can now be configured to ignore setMapNode.  Some ins…
column20: …tances require having a NULL map.
column21:
This fixes a problem we are experiencing in our software where we create LocalGeometryNode instances with an intentionally NULL map that are attached to nodes in our scene.  When we reload the map, the MapNodeObserver comes in and, trying to be helpful, assigns the map node.  This breaks the display.  The use case is an extruded relative line overlay.
We can possibly address this in our own code base however, so if this is not a solution you want to see, feel free to close the PR and we can look for an application level solution.

column13: Remove limitation of only supporting one earth file element in included xml files.
column20:
Included xml files via xml xi:include tag currently supports only
one earth file element because xml files require a top level xml
tag. This limitation is fixed by adding support for an xml 
element as top level xml tag.
see bug #800

column21:
Thanks for the PR. At this time we don't think this the right solution. Generally speaking (in GIS tools e.g.) a Group Layer connotes the ability to operate on the layer as a Group in all capacities (toggling visibility, changing render order, and so on), while your approach is only a deserialization semantic. It also doesn't persist in the Map model, so the group will not be present if you re-serialize the same MapNode.
We have contemplated the idea of Group layers quite a few times over the years but have not implemented them because the concept does carry these expectations.

column21: What problem are you trying to solve here? Are you seeing a bug?

column13: Change the _models order in the MapNode
column20:
The models should be visited before the OverlayDecorator, during a
culling traversal, so that the cullOverlayGroup method in DrapingTechnique
or ClampingTechnique may work correctly.
column21:
When I was tracking the program, I found that the OverlayDecorator is visited before the models that uses draping technique.
I think the drapable models should be visited first and be collected in the DrapingCullSet, so that the DrapableNodes  are traversed later in the DrapingCamera which is done when the  cullOverlayGroup method of DrapingTechnique is invoked.

ReaderWriterWMS: Locale independent bounds serialization
column20:
BBOX of eight numbers? It's true for locale with desimal point is the ,.
Use the sprintf function is not safe here. The result depends on the locale.
The result is an improper URL request which can not be recognized cartographic server.
This request is a patch for a quick solution to the problem. Probably it is necessary to improve the implementation, but I have no time to do it. I just want to draw attention to the problem.

column13: VAO support
column20:
Hey Glenn
Here are the changes merged into master. It's actually just adding a vertex buffer object to for the texture coords and switching VAOs on.
Basically you can bind and unbind vbos while a vao is bound your just kind of losing the benefit of vaos. The issues where being caused by the fact the texture coords where sharing their vbos, altering that in vao was the issue.
Previously I did have to override createVertexArrayState in MPGeometry as their weren't enough array dispatchers allocated for the other texture cord channels, but that crash seems to have disappeared.
Anyhow it runs on my mac with a GL3 context.

column13: Lighting: Performance improvements to MaterialCallback
column20:
Addresses two issues.  First, strings are not created on the fly but are instead using a static const, to prevent excessive string constructor/destructors.
Second, the setUpdateCallback for a Material Callback only called in cases where the DYNAMIC property is set.  This is intended to eliminate constant setting of uniforms in the update callback in the common case where material properties are set but not changed.
column21:
Addresses two issues.  First, strings are not created on the fly but are instead using a static const, to prevent excessive string constructor/destructors.
Second, the setUpdateCallback for a Material Callback only called in cases where the DYNAMIC property is set.  This is intended to eliminate constant setting of uniforms in the update callback in the common case where material properties are set but not changed.

column13: Add USE_QT4 to allow building with Qt4 when Qt5 also present
column20:
I'm building osgEarth to support the Globe plugin for QGIS. QGIS stable is still recommending Qt4 at this time but I also have Qt5 installed. Currently osgEarth will automatically build for Qt5 for me.
This is my quick solution, adding a USE_QT4 option. Submitting here in case it is useful for others.
Without USE_QT4 it will still build for Qt5 if installed. It won't automatically fallback from trying Qt5 to try Qt4 - arguably that's an improvement.
Happy to change the logic, create a OSGEARTH_USE_QT4? etc. Possibly CMake should fail if OSGEARTH_USE_QT is set and no Qt is found.

column13: Re added createVertexArrayStates fix
column20:
Hi Glenn
Remo ran into an issue I was previously having with VAO on OSX but I thought it had been fixed within osg. Turns out it hadn't
So the change to MPGeometry is required because on line 239 of MPGeometry.cpp a texture coord unit is used that wasn't part of the geometry texture arrays. This means no vertex array dispatcher was created for it so it crashes.
I feel like it should nearly always crash, but it seems fine in some cases and like I said it stopped crashing on me, but a .earth file with no layers causes it to happen still.
The fix is pretty ugly I think, but it works and I've made it only apply when VOAs are in use as no one else seems to have the issue.
I also fixed a small compiler error in HTTPClient.cpp
My topic-vao-osx branch was merged with latest master before I did these changes

column13: 2.8 - GDAL static linking support and Visual Studio build fixes
column20:
Support linking GDAL statically (this requires that we initialized the GDAL and OGR drivers for each shared library that uses GDAL).
Added /FORCE:MULTIPLE for MSVC to fix several projects that weren't building on VS2013 because of multiple definition errors given for ostream.  (This is a fairly well-known workaround for link errors in osgDB with visual studio).
column21:
Support linking GDAL statically (this requires that we initialized the GDAL and OGR drivers for each shared library that uses GDAL).
Added /FORCE:MULTIPLE for MSVC to fix several projects that weren't building on VS2013 because of multiple definition errors given for ostream.  (This is a fairly well-known workaround for link errors in osgDB with visual studio).

column13: 2.8 - GDAL static linking support and Visual Studio build fixes
column20:
Support linking GDAL statically (this requires that we initialized the GDAL and OGR drivers for each shared library that uses GDAL).
Added /FORCE:MULTIPLE for MSVC to fix several projects that weren't building on VS2013 because of multiple definition errors given for ostream.  (This is a fairly well-known workaround for link errors in osgDB with visual studio).
column21:
Note, the general idea for change was suggested by Jason Beverage here: http://forum.osgearth.org/Issues-with-static-GDAL-library-and-ESRI-Shapefiles-td7590477.html
I realize there's a bit of copy-paste in how I set up the GDAL initializers -- there are multiple InitGDAL.cpp files with basically the same code in them.  I did this because IIRC CMake is not keen on you adding source files from parent directories, meaning I didn't really have a way of sharing the same .cpp file between multiple projects.  Let me know if you know a better way of doing it...

column13: 2.8 - GDAL static linking support and Visual Studio build fixes

Added /FORCE:MULTIPLE for MSVC to fix several projects that weren't building on VS2013 because of multiple definition errors given for ostream.  (This is a fairly well-known workaround for link errors in osgDB with visual studio).

column13: Added conditional support for exp2 to fix MSVC 2010 and 2012 builds.
column20: Added an ifdef around exp2 usage, which is not available on all compilers.  An alternate solution is to replace exp2 with pow(2.0, dL), but there are possibly performance or precision issues with that solution.

column13: MBTiles and GDAL drivers now use osgDB to find URLs to open.
column20: We have custom modifications in our application to enhance the OSG search path with our own routines.  This patch modifies mbtiles and gdal drivers to fall back to osgDB when files can't be found, allowing our search to find the files.

column13: GLES 3 compile support
column20:
Changes to gles3 compiling on iOS. Also begun changes to insert correct glsl version and default precision into shaders.
In osgEarthUtils Controls.cpp line 706 _autoTransformCache no longer exists in osgText so I've added a temp compile fix that just uses _matrix rather than the cache matrix but I'm not sure if this is correct.
The merge shader path in virtual program now supports shader versions with a sub version part like '300 es', it also removes redefinintions of global variables as these cause errors on gles
Big improvements to cmake support on iOS, now generates an application example that can be built out of the box.
column21:
Changes to gles3 compiling on iOS. Also begun changes to insert correct glsl version and default precision into shaders.
In osgEarthUtils Controls.cpp line 706 _autoTransformCache no longer exists in osgText so I've added a temp compile fix that just uses _matrix rather than the cache matrix but I'm not sure if this is correct.
The merge shader path in virtual program now supports shader versions with a sub version part like '300 es', it also removes redefinintions of global variables as these cause errors on gles
Big improvements to cmake support on iOS, now generates an application example that can be built out of the box.

column13: Allow side-by-side installation of osgEarth compiled against Qt4 and Qt5
column20:
Add the DESIRED_QT_VERSION CMake option to control whether osgEarthQt is compiled against Qt4 or Qt5 (following the convention of osgQt which also uses DESIRED_QT_VERSION)
Allow conflict-free side-by-side installation of osgEarthQt compiled against Qt4 and Qt5 by renaming specifying Qt5 as appropriate in the libraries and examples compiled against Qt5, following the convention used by upstream Qt (i.e. libQt5Core):

osgEarthQt5
osgearth_package_qt5
osgearth_qt5_simple
osgearth_qt5_windows


Preserve <osgEarthQt/...> include paths. Since headers are identical between osgEarthQt and osgEarthQt5, there is no point distinguishing them and breaking applications which #include <osgEarthQt/...>.
Look for osgQt5 for Qt5 build if OpenSceneGraph version is newer or equal 3.5.6.

See also openscenegraph/osgQt#3, openscenegraph/osgQt#4.

column13: Windows GLCore/GL3 support and GL3 compile fixes
column20:
This support Core GL3 compile on Windows. It is the same as in OSG:
http://forum.openscenegraph.org/viewtopic.php?t=13457
https://github.com/openscenegraph/OpenSceneGraph/blob/5d6322da2b84470fc0675b1c637246acb58802e9/CMakeModules/OsgMacroUtils.cmake#L214
I've testes it on Windows x64 with master branch and OSG 3.5.6 release.
About the GL3 fixes:
GL_DEPTH_BITS and GL_CLIP_PLANE0  is deprecated on GL3. And it doesn't build with core profile without this changes.

It was working before but something seems to have crept in and I keep having issues with trianglefunctor type code crashing the app since osg added that new triange code. I just want to get this merged though as none of this has anything to do with that I it's getting a bit difficult to keep it up to date with the osgearth master.
Thanks
Tom

column13: Give CQL_FILTER priority over BBOX if both WFS parameters are set
column20:
Issue: In a WFS feature model has layout defined it implicitly sets the BBOX WFS parameter, and this would override any explicitly set SQL_FILTER in the query expression property since BBOX and CQL_FILTER are mutually exclusive.
Fix: Test is whether expression (i.e. CQL_FILTER) is available before BBOX to give it priority.
column21:
Issue: In a WFS feature model has layout defined it implicitly sets the BBOX WFS parameter, and this would override any explicitly set SQL_FILTER in the query expression property since BBOX and CQL_FILTER are mutually exclusive.
Fix: Test is whether expression (i.e. CQL_FILTER) is available before BBOX to give it priority.

column13: Fixes gdal-mutex crash-on-exit.
column20: On gcc global cleanup local static variables are deleted before global static variables. To ensure that gdal_mutex is alive when registry destructs it has been moved into the class Registry.
column21: On gcc global cleanup local static variables are deleted before global static variables. To ensure that gdal_mutex is alive when registry destructs it has been moved into the class Registry.

column13: Fixes gdal-mutex crash-on-exit.
column20: On gcc global cleanup local static variables are deleted before global static variables. To ensure that gdal_mutex is alive when registry destructs it has been moved into the class Registry.
column21:
Thanks for looking into this!  I'm hesitant to take this change though as is without some further investigation.
We've had issues with applications crashing on exit related to the GDAL mutex before, and we've tried moving it around to various places that will fix one application but cause a crash in another.  It's all related to the static creation and destruction order of variables, so we need to look a bit further into the relationship between the various places in osgEarth that use the gdal mutex and ensure that everything is created and destroyed in the right order.

column13: Fixes gdal-mutex crash-on-exit.
column20: On gcc global cleanup local static variables are deleted before global static variables. To ensure that gdal_mutex is alive when registry destructs it has been moved into the class Registry.
column21:
We've been experiencing sporadic issues on application close on Windows for the last 6-9 months or so.  This wasn't a problem before then.  I can test on my side to see if this helps our crashing bug if that's helpful.
Edit: FWIW, it does resolve our crash-on-exit bug in Windows too.

column13: CMake: Respect OSG_DIR when searching for OSG version.
column20:
Recent change to OSG version detection broke versioning when OSG_DIR was specified by itself.  This change lets OSG_INCLUDE_DIR fall back to OSG_DIR/include.
We have build scripts that specify OSG_DIR that lets osgEarth figure out the include path etc., as per FindOSG.cmake in line 27 (preferred path for OSG is OSG_DIR).  This change lets those build scripts continue to work.  Without this, the version on first configure is empty-string, leading to bad RPATH on Linux and incorrect install location.
column21:
Recent change to OSG version detection broke versioning when OSG_DIR was specified by itself.  This change lets OSG_INCLUDE_DIR fall back to OSG_DIR/include.
We have build scripts that specify OSG_DIR that lets osgEarth figure out the include path etc., as per FindOSG.cmake in line 27 (preferred path for OSG is OSG_DIR).  This change lets those build scripts continue to work.  Without this, the version on first configure is empty-string, leading to bad RPATH on Linux and incorrect install location.

column13: Cache wms, wfs, and tms metadata per service
column20:
If a system has intermittent network issue (e.g. like at an IBC booth), you might not get some layer in an earth file at all if network connection breaks when metadata for layers are read (e.g. WFS Capabilities), event though all tiles are cached locally.
This commit is a hackish solution that caches WFS/WMS/TMS metacast data to disc when read successfully. If then at a later load of an earth file, the network connection is broken at the time when metadata is read, the cached metadata is used.
We would like to see these changes evolve into a propper feature, so that:

metadata caching can be configured (Enable/disable, age-threshhold, etc.)
solution is made platform indepedent and consistent with osgEarth data cache config.

column13: Endian: MSVC 2010 support.  Unit test added for little endian systems.
column20:
Commits from yesterday broke MSVC 2010 build.  This change not only fixes MSVC 2010 but verifies behavior via unit test.
stdint.h is required for uint32_t support on MSVC 2010.  htonll and ntohll are not defined in winsock2.h for MSVC 2010 and _byteswap_uint64 can be used in their place.
Unit test verified correct operation on 64 bit systems: MSVC 2010, MSVC 2012, MSVC 2015, and Linux g++ 4.8.  I also tested it on a MSVC 2010 32 bit system.
Also includes minor typo fixes in another test.
column21:
Commits from yesterday broke MSVC 2010 build.  This change not only fixes MSVC 2010 but verifies behavior via unit test.
stdint.h is required for uint32_t support on MSVC 2010.  htonll and ntohll are not defined in winsock2.h for MSVC 2010 and _byteswap_uint64 can be used in their place.
Unit test verified correct operation on 64 bit systems: MSVC 2010, MSVC 2012, MSVC 2015, and Linux g++ 4.8.  I also tested it on a MSVC 2010 32 bit system.
Also includes minor typo fixes in another test.

column13: To stop the elevation pool threads.
Don't set OPENSCENEGRAPH_VERSION in CMakeLists.txt
column20:
It is already set by DETECT_OSG_VERSION, and OPENSCENEGRAPH_{MAJOR,MINOR,PATCH}_VERSION are not defined anymore since b97eda0, resulting in OPENSCENEGRAPH_VERSION = ".."
Note that currently the logic to pick osgQt5 vs osgQt in https://github.com/gwaldron/osgearth/blob/master/CMakeModules/FindOSG.cmake#L122 is borken due to OPENSCENEGRAPH_VERSION being incorrectly set.

column13: Allow a folder to be referrer
column20: This is very useful when embedding earth files into other files though ReaderWriter::writeNode(const osg::Node&, std::ostream&, const Options*). This allows us to have a fix setup root reference for all resources.
column21: The usecase is where .earth file is streamed as an embedded element into a larger datastructure (project) that will be written to disc at a later stage. Hence, at the point where we need to serialize the MapNode, the referrer file does not yet exist. An one existing referrer file results file references within the MapNode layers to be written with absolute paths. This is why we want to be able to set a directory as referrer.

column13: Allow a folder to be referrer

column21:
Hi Glenn,
No luck reproducing the issue. The TMS urls to readymap are serialized just fine. What exactly happened to URLs in you test. If it is the windows implementation POSIX "stat" that messes the URL up, then please try to following work-around. This pr and use-case are important to us :
diff --git a/src/osgEarthDrivers/earth/EarthFileSerializer2.cpp b/src/osgEarthDrivers/earth/EarthFileSerializer2.cpp
index 75ff516..4608349 100644
--- a/src/osgEarthDrivers/earth/EarthFileSerializer2.cpp
+++ b/src/osgEarthDrivers/earth/EarthFileSerializer2.cpp
@@ -182,9 +182,16 @@ namespace
         {
             _rewriteAbsolutePaths = false;
             _newReferrerAbsPath = osgDB::convertFileNameToUnixStyle( osgDB::getRealPath(referrer) );
-           // Check whether referrer is file or folder.
            struct stat sb;
+#if 1
+           // If referrer is local (i.e. starts with slash, not "<protocol>://"), then
+           // check whether referrer is file or folder.
+           if (!_newReferrerAbsPath.empty() && (_newReferrerAbsPath.substr(0,1) == "/")
+                   && stat(_newReferrerAbsPath.c_str(), &sb) == 0 && S_ISDIR(sb.st_mode))
+#else
+           // Check whether referrer is file or folder.
            if (stat(_newReferrerAbsPath.c_str(), &sb) == 0 && S_ISDIR(sb.st_mode))
+#endif
                _newReferrerFolder = _newReferrerAbsPath;
            else
                _newReferrerFolder  = osgDB::getFilePath( osgDB::findDataFile(_newReferrerAbsPath) );

column13: Fix bug in ElevationLayerVector::populateHeightFieldAndNormalMap
column20:
commit 4b89793 optimized copying of
TileKey objects by using references, but these references could
clobber keys in the contenders array that will still be used. Scratch
space for actualKey is now used if necessary.
If the border code is re-enabled, then this bug will need to be fixed for
contenderKey as well.
The test case I used was osgearth_lights boston_projected.earth. The
bug prevents buildings from appearing.

column13: PixelAutoTransform: LOD Scale now only applies if changing scale, and…
column20: … it resets back after cull traversal.
column21:
We were seeing a problem in orthographic overhead mode in the SIMDIS SDK with this code.  We need to dynamically adjust the LOD scale based on perceived eye position vs actual eye position in Ortho mode to fix the LODs on loaded entity models.  We got it working, but because PixelAutoTransform is a child, it was resetting our LOD scale back to 1.  I also saw an issue where PAT was changing the LOD scale not just for its children, but for everything else in the cull visitation after it.
Sorry for the short update, had test code in to ensure this was required, and I forgot to take it out before initial PR.

column13: DrapeableNode is now a MapNodeObserver.
column20:
This fixes two problems:

DrapeableNode may not be in the NodePath of a MapNode, so its update traversal never finds an initial MapNode.  setMapNode() gives users a way to configure it properly externally.
The Map Node may change at runtime and DrapeableNode would not catch the change.
column21:

column13: DrapeableNode is now a MapNodeObserver.
column20:
This fixes two problems:

DrapeableNode may not be in the NodePath of a MapNode, so its update traversal never finds an initial MapNode.  setMapNode() gives users a way to configure it properly externally.
The Map Node may change at runtime and DrapeableNode would not catch the change.
column21: Dan, the long-term plan was to get away from the MapNodeObserver pattern (which I think is messy) and eventually just require that AnnotationNodes (or any kind of Drapable/Clampable) be a descendant of MapNode. I feel like this makes sense since they depend on the map/terrain for their operation anyway. Thoughts?

column13: DrapeableNode is now a MapNodeObserver.
column20:
This fixes two problems:

DrapeableNode may not be in the NodePath of a MapNode, so its update traversal never finds an initial MapNode.  setMapNode() gives users a way to configure it properly externally.
The Map Node may change at runtime and DrapeableNode would not catch the change.
column21:
How would you deal with change in the MapNode?  For example, when the MapNode changes in this case, the observer_ptr becomes invalidated, but the update traversal has already been turned off so you'll not catch new MapNodes.  You could keep update traversal on, but there's a performance cost to that and it results in unnecessary polling, since 99.99% of the time on update you won't have a map change.
Maybe it's messy, but it's also more cost efficient than the update traversal approach.
It would also more deeply complicate what we're currently during with the node layout in simVis::SceneManager.  I do not offhand know the ramifications of making everything a child of the map again.  I do know that we'd need to be more careful about displacing the old MapNode with the new MapNode, replacing children as needed.  Shouldn't be a big deal, but I just don't know offhand whether we'll have any graphics ramifications of this.  For example, we turn off depth writing in some cases on the terrain, but want it turned back on for entities.  We'll just need to make sure we cover that on our side.

column13: DrapeableNode is now a MapNodeObserver.

column21: OK, so lots of issues there. I'll merge this for now and we can discuss it all at a later time. In a perfect world there would be no need to replace a MapNode at all ... rather just call setMap etc. and move on.

column13: Used unused config URI::option_string to configure custom CURL headers
column20:
The prime reason for sending custom curl headers through the unused URI::option_string is to enable configuration of oauth2 bearer token for sources protected by oauth2 authentication (Ref. ECMWF data at https://thredds.met.no/thredds/metno.html).
Example imagelayer accessing WMS restricted by oauth2:
    <image name="met-no-ecmwf-air-temperature" driver="wms">
        <url>https://thredds.met.no/thredds/wms/ecmwf/atmo/ec_atmo_0_1deg_20180118T120000Z_pl.nc</url>
	<option_string>Authorization: Bearer YOUR-TOKEN-STRING</option_string>
        <format>png</format>
	<version>1.3.0</version>
        <layers>air_temperature_pl</layers>
        <tile_size>256</tile_size>
        <srs>EPSG:4326</srs>
        <transparent>true</transparent>
        <times>2018-01-18T18:00:00.000Z</times>
        <cache_policy usage="no_cache"/>
    </image>

Passing URI::option_string as CURL custom header has been enabled for: TFS. WFS, TMS, WMS, and XYZ.
Note 1: Instead of using URI::option_string for passing CURL custom headers, it could be preferable to add URI::curl_header config, or even make it possible to add a list of custom CURL headers.
Note 2: CURLOPT_XOAUTH2_BEARER was not used, since it is not supported by current curl version on CentOS7 (curl-7.29.0)
Note 3: It would be possible to omit using osgDB::Options::pluginStringData if urls were passed as URI classes rather than std::string. However, this would be a much larger code change.

column21: John, the option_string property isn't unused. It is specifically for passing plugin-specific information to a OSG loader (jpeg, png, etc.) via the osgDB::Options::setOptionString() call. Because of this, I tend to agree with your "Note 1" in that custom HTTP headers will likely require a property separate from option_string.  But it's up for discussion :)

column21:
John,
We discussed this internally. I think the approach we want to take is to add a set of custom "fields" to the URIContext object. These would be name/value pairs that the HTTPClient could then interpret as headers. Being in the URIContext would ensure that they get propagated nicely -- since it's likely that if you want the custom headers for one operation, relative-URI operations will want the same set of headers.
I think it makes the most sense to incorporate this post-2.9 at this point.

column13: Added new optional http_header config to osgEarth::URI
column20:
The new URL::http_header config is used to pass custom http header to Curl in osgEarth::HTTPClient.
The prime reason for adding the URI::http_header is to enable configuration of oauth2 bearer token for sources protected by oauth2 authentication (Ref. ECMWF data at https://thredds.met.no/thredds/metno.html).
Example imagelayer accessing WMS restricted by oauth2:
   <image name="met-no-ecmwf-air-temperature" driver="wms">
      <url>https://thredds.met.no/thredds/wms/ecmwf/atmo/ec_atmo_0_1deg_20180118T120000Z_pl.nc</url>
      <http_header>Authorization: Bearer YOUR-TOKEN-STRING</http_header>
      <format>png</format>
      <version>1.3.0</version>
      <layers>air_temperature_pl</layers>
      <tile_size>256</tile_size>
      <srs>EPSG:4326</srs>
      <transparent>true</transparent>
      <times>2018-01-18T18:00:00.000Z</times>
      <cache_policy usage="no_cache"/>
   </image>

Passing URI::http_header to CURL has been enabled for: TFS. WFS, TMS, WMS, and XYZ.
Note 1: CURLOPT_XOAUTH2_BEARER was not used, since it is not supported by current curl version on CentOS7 (curl-7.29.0)
Note 2: It would be possible to omit using osgDB::Options::pluginStringData if urls were passed as URI classes rather than std::string. However, this would be a much larger code change.
column21:
The new URL::http_header config is used to pass custom http header to Curl in osgEarth::HTTPClient.
The prime reason for adding the URI::http_header is to enable configuration of oauth2 bearer token for sources protected by oauth2 authentication (Ref. ECMWF data at https://thredds.met.no/thredds/metno.html).
Example imagelayer accessing WMS restricted by oauth2:
   <image name="met-no-ecmwf-air-temperature" driver="wms">
      <url>https://thredds.met.no/thredds/wms/ecmwf/atmo/ec_atmo_0_1deg_20180118T120000Z_pl.nc</url>
      <http_header>Authorization: Bearer YOUR-TOKEN-STRING</http_header>
      <format>png</format>
      <version>1.3.0</version>
      <layers>air_temperature_pl</layers>
      <tile_size>256</tile_size>
      <srs>EPSG:4326</srs>
      <transparent>true</transparent>
      <times>2018-01-18T18:00:00.000Z</times>
      <cache_policy usage="no_cache"/>
   </image>

Passing URI::http_header to CURL has been enabled for: TFS. WFS, TMS, WMS, and XYZ.
Note 1: CURLOPT_XOAUTH2_BEARER was not used, since it is not supported by current curl version on CentOS7 (curl-7.29.0)
Note 2: It would be possible to omit using osgDB::Options::pluginStringData if urls were passed as URI classes rather than std::string. However, this would be a much larger code change.

column13: cache_rocksdb: fix linking issues on msys2/mingw with latest rocksdb
column20:
Compile cache_rocksdb with latest rocksdb had two issues:

cmake could not find librocksdb as it was searching for rocksdblib
linking cache_rocksdb failed because libraries needed by rocksdb were listed before rocksdb

This PR attempts to address both issues.
With the proposed changes osgearth and cache_rocksdb compile fine.

column21: Hi Philippe!  Thanks for this PR.  I didn't merge it as is, but I used it for inspiration in my commit cc17e47 that adds support for GDAL 2.0's new support for specifying a resampling algorithm during RasterIO operations.  Having an internal rasterio is a great place to isolate differences between the 1.x and 2.x branches of gdal, thanks for the idea!  I think my commit also addresses your unused return value warning, if you can check on your end and see that would be awesome.  Thanks again!

column13: Map: addLayer() now puts the new layer in a ref_ptr to prevent accide…
column20: …ntal deletion during callback processing.
column21: This fixes a crash bug when Elevation Layers in a .earth file are set with visible=false.  Without this, the first pass of map callbacks ends up putting the layer in a ref_ptr that is then discarded, which deletes the layer mid-processing of callbacks, causing a segfault.

column21:
Hi @filnet ,

I am a maintainer of the MSYS2/MinGW osgEarth package.
osgEarth builds fine there without GEOS_INLINE defined

Could you show your build rules?

I was wondering what issue you had

[ 26%] Built target osgEarth
[ 26%] Linking CXX shared library ../../lib/libosgEarthSymbology.dll
CMakeFiles/osgEarthSymbology.dir/objects.a(GEOS.cpp.obj):GEOS.cpp:(.text+0xda): undefined reference to `geos::geom::PrecisionModel::~PrecisionModel()'
CMakeFiles/osgEarthSymbology.dir/objects.a(GEOS.cpp.obj):GEOS.cpp:(.text+0x248): undefined reference to `geos::geom::Coordinate::Coordinate(double, double, double)'
CMakeFiles/osgEarthSymbology.dir/objects.a(GEOS.cpp.obj):GEOS.cpp:(.text+0x4ce): undefined reference to `geos::geom::GeometryFactory::getCoordinateSequenceFactory() const'
CMakeFiles/osgEarthSymbology.dir/objects.a(GEOS.cpp.obj):GEOS.cpp:(.text+0x55e): undefined reference to `geos::geom::GeometryFactory::getCoordinateSequenceFactory() const'
CMakeFiles/osgEarthSymbology.dir/objects.a(GEOS.cpp.obj):GEOS.cpp:(.text+0x6ab): undefined reference to `geos::geom::GeometryFactory::getCoordinateSequenceFactory() const'
CMakeFiles/osgEarthSymbology.dir/objects.a(GEOS.cpp.obj):GEOS.cpp:(.text+0x714): undefined reference to `geos::geom::GeometryFactory::getCoordinateSequenceFactory() const'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
make[2]: *** [src/osgEarthSymbology/CMakeFiles/osgEarthSymbology.dir/build.make:1208: lib/libosgEarthSymbology.dll] Error 1
make[1]: *** [CMakeFiles/Makefile2:331: src/osgEarthSymbology/CMakeFiles/osgEarthSymbology.dir/all] Error 2
make: *** [Makefile:152: all] Error 2


what that define does

https://github.com/OSGeo/geos/blob/master/src/inlines.cpp

and how it fixes the issue you are facing ?

It fixes linking with shared GEOS libraries.

I am asking because the proposed change will affect the MSYS2/MINGW build too...

Ok, let's check it.

PS : seems you where able to set GEOS_INLINE on your side (i.e. mxe) so I am wondering if this PR is still relevant ?

Usage of -DCMAKE_CXX_FLAGS='-DGEOS_INLINE=1' (as you see in mxe/mxe@a118ee0) is not a solution of problem, but just another way to workaround it. We will use it if necessary. But providing patches for upstream is more preferable way.

column13: Fix build with libgeos using MinGW
column20: Fixed linking of osgEarthSymbology with geos when build as shared library using MinGW.
column21:
This is how osgEarth is built by MSYS2/MinGW:
      ${MINGW_PREFIX}/bin/cmake.exe \
        -G"MSYS Makefiles" \
        -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=${MINGW_PREFIX} \
        -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=${builddir%-${MINGW_CHOST}} \
        -DOSG_DIR=${MINGW_PREFIX} \
        -DOSGEARTH_QT_BUILD=ON \
        -DOSGEARTH_QT_BUILD_LEGACY_WIDGETS=ON \
        ${_opts} \
        ../${_realname}-${_pkgver}

DYNAMIC_OSGEARTH is not set so will default to ON.
Currently it builds osgEarth 2.9 with GEOS 3.6.1.

column13: Fix build with libgeos using MinGW
column20: Fixed linking of osgEarthSymbology with geos when build as shared library using MinGW.
column21:
Could the issue come from how GEOS was built by mxe where some symbols were not exported ?
This is how GEOS is built by MSYS2/MinGW:
  ${MINGW_PREFIX}/bin/cmake \
    -G"MSYS Makefiles" \
    -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=${MINGW_PREFIX} \
    -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release \
    -DGEOS_ENABLE_INLINE=OFF \
    ../${_realname}-${pkgver}

I guess it explains why we don't have the issue you are facing.

column13: Fix build with libgeos using MinGW
column20: Fixed linking of osgEarthSymbology with geos when build as shared library using MinGW.
column21:
Could the issue come from how GEOS was built by mxe where some symbols were not exported ?

In MXE the default configuration options are used.

This is how GEOS is built by MSYS2/MinGW:
...
    -DGEOS_ENABLE_INLINE=OFF \
...

This is why you do not have a linking error. Why have you disabled GEOS_ENABLE_INLINE?

column13: Fix build with libgeos using MinGW
column20: Fixed linking of osgEarthSymbology with geos when build as shared library using MinGW.
column21:
Why have you disabled GEOS_ENABLE_INLINE?

I was not the one who did that but I guess it was done to avoid the issue you faced.
By building GEOS with GEOS_ENABLE_INLINE to ON you then force all other projects to enable it on their side when using GEOS.
The person who contributed GEOS to MSYS2/MinGW probably decided to not put that constraint on GEOS users.

column13: Fixed bug of explicitly loading osgEarthUtil library in the ReaderWri…
column20:
…terOsgEarth.cpp file
In Debug configuration explicitly loaded Release version of osgEarthUtil library.
To reproduce the bug, run the command:
$ OSGEARTH_NOTIFY_LEVEL=DEBUG osgearth_viewerd simple.earth
[osgEarth]  [Earth Plugin] Forced load: libosgEarthUtil.so
…


Reason: incorrectly detected Debug configuration in the src/osgEarthDrivers/earth/ReaderWriterOsgEarth.cpp file. For this purpose, MS Visual Studio specific macro _DEBUG and Qt specific macro QT_DEBUG are used.
Also, RelWithDebInfo and MinSizeRel configuration are not handled.
In addition, in the src\osgEarthDrivers\fastdxt\CMakeLists.txt file defined OSGEARTH_DEBUG_POSTFIX and OSGEARTH_RELEASE_POSTFIX macro, but never used. They are removed to prevent misuse with RelWithDebInfo and MinSizeRel configuration.
column21:
…terOsgEarth.cpp file
In Debug configuration explicitly loaded Release version of osgEarthUtil library.
To reproduce the bug, run the command:
$ OSGEARTH_NOTIFY_LEVEL=DEBUG osgearth_viewerd simple.earth
[osgEarth]  [Earth Plugin] Forced load: libosgEarthUtil.so
…


Reason: incorrectly detected Debug configuration in the src/osgEarthDrivers/earth/ReaderWriterOsgEarth.cpp file. For this purpose, MS Visual Studio specific macro _DEBUG and Qt specific macro QT_DEBUG are used.
Also, RelWithDebInfo and MinSizeRel configuration are not handled.
In addition, in the src\osgEarthDrivers\fastdxt\CMakeLists.txt file defined OSGEARTH_DEBUG_POSTFIX and OSGEARTH_RELEASE_POSTFIX macro, but never used. They are removed to prevent misuse with RelWithDebInfo and MinSizeRel configuration.

column13: Fixed bug of explicitly loading osgEarthUtil library in the ReaderWri…

…terOsgEarth.cpp file
In Debug configuration explicitly loaded Release version of osgEarthUtil library.
To reproduce the bug, run the command:
$ OSGEARTH_NOTIFY_LEVEL=DEBUG osgearth_viewerd simple.earth
[osgEarth]  [Earth Plugin] Forced load: libosgEarthUtil.so
…


Reason: incorrectly detected Debug configuration in the src/osgEarthDrivers/earth/ReaderWriterOsgEarth.cpp file. For this purpose, MS Visual Studio specific macro _DEBUG and Qt specific macro QT_DEBUG are used.
Also, RelWithDebInfo and MinSizeRel configuration are not handled.
In addition, in the src\osgEarthDrivers\fastdxt\CMakeLists.txt file defined OSGEARTH_DEBUG_POSTFIX and OSGEARTH_RELEASE_POSTFIX macro, but never used. They are removed to prevent misuse with RelWithDebInfo and MinSizeRel configuration.

column20: …eprecated osg::Array::BIND_ enums.
column21:
I was having problems with the GL CORE 3.3 build of osgEarth and the SIMDIS SDK with some basic examples.  I tracked down some crashes and bad behavior in SDK to this type of code.
In particular, OSG does not seem to like the deprecated setNormalArrayBinding() call any more in 3.6.0-rc2+.  During runtime if in GL CORE without FFP, you see an error about invalid operations in GL.  This patch fixes a few of those errors.  I updated the color and vertex binding too to be similar.
I did not hit every location that was used.  There is some mesh code that still uses the osg::Geometry enums and I'm hesitant to change that because I'm not familiar with it at all, and it doesn't follow the patterns seen in this commit.

column20: … flashing bug by removing the near/far ratio on stars camera.
column21:
I tested this in both 3.4.1 (against GL 4.5 with compatibility mode) and in 3.6.0-rc4 (against GL 3.3 with core mode).
This does backout part of the fixes from 4e040c5b but this should be better supported, at least in OSG 3.4+ due to variable locations on the color array.  In my 3.6 testing the color attribs were at location 2, not 3.  OSG's replacement scheme in Program seems to take care of this.
The near/far clip plane removal fixes a flickering seen on some video cards, presumably due to a float precision issue with the clip plane.

column13: MacOSX: fix for #1098
MacOSX: fix for #1098
column21:
Hey Remo!
I believe you that this fixes the issue, but I want to understand why to see if we can do a more general fix.  The default attribute location for the ObjectIndex is SECONDARY_COLORS (which is attribute location 4).  Changing it to 8 is changing it to TEXTURE_COORDS_0, which doesn't seem like what you would want to do.  I believe the enum locations are setup to map to nvidia's driver attribute locations, but I'm sure that is different on OSX.
Do you have a feel for what the core issue is here?  Is using attribute location 4 (SECONDARY_COLORS) stomping on the something in the osx driver that isn't an issue on windows?  What about using attribute 5 (FOG_COORDS), would that work instead?

column13: MacOSX: fix for #1098
column21: Hey @remoe , any update on this?  I'm hesitant to make this chance unless we understand why it's working.    If we could make a change that would just work out of the box on all platforms that would make more sense than just changing it in the example.  Have you tried using FOG_COORDS for the attribute position on osx?

column13: MacOSX: fix for #1098
column21:
It's not a correct fix. I think something is wrong with setUseVertexAttributeAliasing in a GLCore environment. I see errors like on MacOSX:
ERROR: Active attribute aliasing. Slot 4 unavailable for 'oe_index_objectid_attr' from BindAttributeLocation request.

But i don't see this on Windows GLCore (OSG 3.6.2). setUseVertexAttributeAliasing  force to bind all this default attributes:
https://github.com/openscenegraph/OpenSceneGraph/blob/6cd00edd6c604dcb9156bf657560823cfdea07ec/src/osg/Program.cpp#L780
This attribute aliasing should work:
https://www.khronos.org/registry/OpenGL-Refpages/gl4/html/glBindAttribLocation.xhtml
But I'm not sure it works on MacOSX GL 4.1

column13: Triton: GL3 fixes to get Ocean drawing with GL Core profile without e…
column20: …rrors.
column21:
The openGLVersion check applies the correct Triton version.  However this is now protected against change from an ifndef on OSG_GL_FIXED_FUNCTION_AVAILABLE.  This is because out of the box, Triton 3.91 will fail with anything but OPENGL_2_0 due to an error in VAO handling.
The WATER_DECALS issue was a problem both in 3.91 and 4.01 in core profile.  It is not a problem in compatibility profile for 3.91, but based on my reading of the code there is typically not a shader installed here anyways.
The mode validity prevents OSG from setting GL_LIGHTING on the next state change.  This should only be needed in Core profile mode, as the flag is deprecated in 3.2
After this series of changes, I now have Triton drawing an ocean in examples in Linux g++ 4.4 and Windows MSVC 2015 x64 against 3.91.  I tested Linux in 4.01 but decided against upgrading for now, so I didn't get around to testing Windows on that side.

column13: Triton: Fix Linux compile error with reinterpret_cast on g++ 4.4
column20:
On Windows, TextureHandle is a pointer and a reinterpret_cast<> is appropriate.  On Linux, it's an int, and at least on g++ 4.4 it's illegal to reinterpret_cast<> a size_t to an int.  Similarly, it's illegal to reinterpret_cast<> an int to a size_t.
An alternate fix should be to use static_cast<> on Linux (based on if _WIN32) and use the preprocessor, but that looked more messy than just having a C-style cast.
column21:
On Windows, TextureHandle is a pointer and a reinterpret_cast<> is appropriate.  On Linux, it's an int, and at least on g++ 4.4 it's illegal to reinterpret_cast<> a size_t to an int.  Similarly, it's illegal to reinterpret_cast<> an int to a size_t.
An alternate fix should be to use static_cast<> on Linux (based on if _WIN32) and use the preprocessor, but that looked more messy than just having a C-style cast.

column13: fast_map: Replaced vector with list to avoid data invalidation in thr…

column13: fast_map: Replaced vector with list to avoid data invalidation in thr…
column20: …eaded use of PerObjectFastMap in HorizonClipPlane::operator().
column21:
osgearth_viewer was consistently crashing for me.  The cause was two threads grabbing data from the PerObjectFastMap in the same HorizonClipPlane.  This was a problem because when the second thread grabbed an entry, it caused the std::vector in fast_map to increment.  That invalidated iterators and references due to a resize in std::vector.  That caused the 'd' reference to become invalid in the first thread, leading to a crash once the first thread got control again.
This was mitigated by replacing the vector with a std::list, which will not invalidate the iterator / data values on insertion.  The primary downsides to this simple fix are that size() is now potentially O(n) (primarily on gcc on older c++ standards), and iteration is possibly slightly slower.

column13: Update Qt OpenGL context to use the version of OpenGL requested via the Qt graphics context setup.
column20:
I am using ViewerWidget to display osgEarth content on Linux using an Intel GPU with Core Profile (GPU supports OpenGL 4.5).
I have set the context version using:
osg::DisplaySettings::instance()->setGLContextVersion("4.5");
However this was not being honored when the ViewerWidget was created, thus resulting in a non Core Profile OpenGL context being created by Qt. The result was a bunch of GLSL compile errors.
This update sets the OpenGL version that Qt is to use. This results in the earth being visible.
column21:

column13: Earth Rewriter: Folder now based on absolute path instead of findData…
column20: …File(), which can return empty string if file not found.  Supports stream-based loading and saving of Earth files instead of file-based.
column21:
We have a use case where a user wants to save off the current earth file with relative paths to a given location.  This normally works with files because the file exists and findDataFile() returns the input as given.  But when you're working with an ostream, there is not necessary a file there, but we still want to be able to get relative paths back from an existing directory.
This removes the findDataFile(), which was returning empty string in this case, instead relying on getRealPath() above to get the absolute path.  If that's good enough for the absolute filename, it should be good enough for the absolute filename's directory too.

column13: PointDrawable: glEnable/Disable(GL_POINT_SPRITE) is not supported for Core Profile
column20:
GL_POINT_SPRITE is always enabled for Core Profile.
This modification stops OSG from calling glEnable/glDisable and
thus producing OpenGL errors when using Core Profile.
column21:
Line 368 of your change sets osg::PointSprite to OFF.  This means the associated mode, GL_POINT_SPRITE, would still be set with glDisable(GL_POINT_SPRITE) somewhere during the frame.
The reason osg::PointSprite is here at all is to trigger the state.setModeValidity(GL_POINT_SPRITE..., modeValid) code in osg::PointSprite::checkValidityOfAssociatedModes().  It also enables the GL_POINT_SPRITE_COORD_ORIGIN properly.  I guess in GL3 it doesn't matter too much if it's on or off, but I guess I don't see why it would be set to off?
Make sure you're running OSG 3.6.2.  openscenegraph/OpenSceneGraph@d01edcb540a4 and openscenegraph/OpenSceneGraph@500d3947e help with correct usage of Point Sprite in a GL3 Core Profile configuration and it can be messy to get point sprite working in both GL Core profile and Compatibility profile without it.

column13: PointDrawable: glEnable/Disable(GL_POINT_SPRITE) is not supported for Core Profile
column20:
GL_POINT_SPRITE is always enabled for Core Profile.
This modification stops OSG from calling glEnable/glDisable and
thus producing OpenGL errors when using Core Profile.
column21: Sorry, in case it wasn't clear, GL_POINT_SPRITE mode can be set or unset as desired.  It is OSG's job to make sure that even if it's applied, it doesn't make it to the driver through a glEnable() or glDisable() job.  It is now doing its job correctly as of 3.6.2.

column13: PointDrawable: glEnable/Disable(GL_POINT_SPRITE) is not supported for Core Profile
column20:
GL_POINT_SPRITE is always enabled for Core Profile.
This modification stops OSG from calling glEnable/glDisable and
thus producing OpenGL errors when using Core Profile.
column21:
For Intel i965, Mesa 18.0.5, GL_ARB_point_sprite is supported.
However this does not mean that glEnable/glDisable is supported by the Core Profile for turning on/off point sprite. The standard says that point sprite is always enabled for Core Profile (hence the OFF in the patch).
This means that OSG is not performing sufficient checks.
Probably better to update OSG, however I don't know my way around OSG particularly well below the api.

column13: PointDrawable: glEnable/Disable(GL_POINT_SPRITE) is not supported for Core Profile

This modification stops OSG from calling glEnable/glDisable and

column21:
I asked on the OSG mailing lists and Robert suggested the following:

The glEnable/glDisable will be done directed by your scene graph via
the StateSet::setMode(GLenum,..), so simply remove the
setMode(GL_POINT_SPRITE).

Its going to probably be a couple of weeks before I get to look t this again.

MGRSGraticule: Fix binary data read on Linux.  unsigned long is 64 bits, not 32, on g++ 4.x x64
column20:
Tested on g++ 4.4.  We've seen this in the past.  MSVC treats long as int, 32 bits.  g++ x64 4.x treats it as a 64 bit long integer.  Easily fixed by swapping to int, which both respect as 32 bits.
I did not update OE_ENCODE_LONG which works just fine and presumes 32 bits.

column13: Triton: OSG built-in uniforms now correctly apply.  Correct program n…
column20: …ow chosen per-camera for TritonDrawable uniforms.
column21: …ow chosen per-camera for TritonDrawable uniforms.

column13: Triton: OSG built-in uniforms now correctly apply.  Correct program n…
column20: …ow chosen per-camera for TritonDrawable uniforms.
column21:
There was a mistake in 83c1ce1f88 that breaks Triton >= 4, but fixed Triton < 4.  Because Version.h was not included (from Triton), the define was never set, so new Triton (4+) is pulling out variables from the wrong program.  This means Triton 4+ never carries over Uniforms; this is now fixed by including Version.h.
The other problem is that Triton shaders might depend on uniforms like osg_ProjectionMatrix in order to detect things like ortho display in shader.  While NativeProgramAdapter correctly found the uniform ID mapping for osg_ProjectionMatrix, it never actually made it to Triton because State::applyModelViewAndProjectionUinformsIfRequired() is the code that actually applies those uniforms to the State, and it isn't run here.  Calling it directly is not appropriate because the _lastAppliedProgramObject is not set.  This change just hits all of the built-ins explicitly.  If the Triton user functions don't use it, there's no change in behavior.  If they do use one, it gets applied.

column13: Fix transparency on the trees
Debug Layer: Fix glyph display for GL_RED and GL_LUMINANCE fonts.
column20:
Using the default global "default font", the debug layer works good.  But if you replace the global font with one that returns glyphs that are GL_RED, the debug layer driver will break.
This change detects GL_RED and GL_LUMINANCE images (since ImageUtils treats them the same), and treats the red value as the image's transparency value.  Instead of writing a supposed-to-be-transparent pixel to the output image, nothing is written if alpha is under 0.5.  That prevents black backgrounds from showing up on the GL_RED case.
I investigated ImageUtils changes but it looks correct.  For general purpose, its reader seems correct, setting the rgb components to r and setting the alpha to 1.0.  I think debug layer driver ought to be accounting for the difference instead.
Another option, not pursued here, is to detect GL_RED, then create a new color (i.e. color = Vec4f(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, color.r())).  That would forgo the continue calls.
column21:

column13: Fix signed integer overflow when computing the threshold.
column20:
osgearth/src/osgEarth/JsonUtils.cpp:2483:54: warning: integer overflow in expression of type ‘osgEarth::Json::Value::Int’ {aka ‘int’} results in ‘-2147483648’ [-Woverflow]
Value::UInt threshold = (isNegative ? Value::UInt(-Value::minInt)
For signed integers, -minInt = maxInt + 1.
This results in an overflow, which is undefined behaviour for signed integers.
Moreover, on most machines, the overflow would wrap around, resulting in the threshold being minInt for negative numbers.
Negative values would always be decoded as double.

column21:
Are you actually seeing a bug? Or just trying to squash a compiler warning? We didn't write this code, so we are hesitant to mess with it unless there is a real problem.

Just the compiler warning.
I don't think it's easily observable, since the only result of this bug is to decode the value as double, which (I haven't checked) should work just fine.
It's potentially slower, and there might be some precision issues, but ultimately minor.
I understand if you do not want to modify the code without a concrete bug as this introduces risk.
It might be worth it if it is a hot code path though. Your call.

column21:
Double checked.  It's not in my Program Files's SilverLining SDK (Full source) directory.  I checked Public Headers there and it's not there.  I do see a Version.h in my Linux build.  I did an uninstall and a reinstall.  I confirmed I'm on 5.009.  The Full source install does not include a Version.h.  I checked Public Headers directory, which has 25 headers, none including Version.h.  A full grep -r through the extracted exe in Program Files does not include the text SILVERLINING_MAJOR_VERSION anywhere.
I'll pass along a note to their team to indicate the problem.  From my side I'm fine with this change here, if you don't mind trying to conditionally compile the calls to DrawObjects() and GetEnvironmentMap() with preprocessor conditionals?  We're happy to update our SilverLining version, it's just a matter of getting the time to do so since we have to rebuild without DX support.
I'm guessing this is a bug with the Windows installer.  I can limp along by copying the one from Linux over since they're the same version.
Edit: The file is there in the 5.31 installer.  Must have just been a bug for 5.009.  As I indicated I'm happy to just copy over the Linux one, no blockers here on Version.h.  Because the file's there in the latest download I did not bother their team with the (fixed) issue.

column21:
It's certainly possible that there was some sort of build or installer
glitch at that time that we never knew about. If so I apologize for the
oversight.

However, I can confirm that Version.h is being generated reliably now. The
solution of just copying over the Version.h from the Linux distribution
seems fine to me. But, a conditional compile of the API changes that
depends not only on the value of our version #define's but also their
existence would do the job too. If they don't exist at all, it's safe to
say you're using a SilverLining version from before the API changes.

Thank you,

Frank Kane
Founder
Sundog Software, LLC

http://www.sundog-soft.com/

http://www.linkedin.com/pub/frank-kane/17/434/764

column21:
Not sure about that. If _db.size() == 0, _db.begin() == _db.end()

Thanks for your attention!
Yes, In normal case, If _db.size() == 0, _db.begin() == _db.end(). But I don't know why, in some special case, If _db.size() == 0, _db.begin() != _db.end() and _db.begin() is a random access iterator.
It may be related to the c.erase (T) function.

column13: Adjustments to shader merger for gles platforms
column20:
Hi Glenn
The new shader merger seems to work fine. I've made a couple of adjustments as we need to force the version in the shader and add an extension on android. Perhaps there might be a cleaner way of doing that but this commit shows what needs doing.
Tom

column13: Serialization unit test and extension serialization fix
column20:
Commit f2b8110 adds unit test for deserialization and re-serialization of earth files
Unit test demonstrates issue where extensions defined in "" section is saved twice. For each load/save cycles the number of saved extension duplicates will accumulate.
Commit 6abf222 fixes accumulation of extension duplicates when an extension is created in the '' section of an earth file (as demonstrated in unit test).
column21:
Commit f2b8110 adds unit test for deserialization and re-serialization of earth files
Unit test demonstrates issue where extensions defined in "" section is saved twice. For each load/save cycles the number of saved extension duplicates will accumulate.
Commit 6abf222 fixes accumulation of extension duplicates when an extension is created in the '' section of an earth file (as demonstrated in unit test).

column13: Fix bounds checking in RTTPicker::pick
column20:
This makes sure we don't read at _offsetX==w nor at _offsetY==h in
SpiralIterator::next(), which would give garbage results.
This fixes #1250.

column13: Windows compile fix
column20: This patch is required to compile osgearth on Windows.
column21:
This class is used inside osgearth (in another dll requiring that this class to be exported), which means that osgearth is not compilable on Windows without this patch: :-(
From https://build.opensuse.org/package/show/home:rhabacker:branches:windows:mingw:win32:Geo/mingw32-osgearth
[  620s] /usr/bin/i686-w64-mingw32-g++  -O2 -g -pipe -Wall -fexceptions --param=ssp-buffer-size=4 -mms-bitfields -O3 -DNDEBUG -Wl,--exclude-libs=libintl.a -Wl,--exclude-libs=libiconv.a -Wl,--no-keep-memory -shared -o ../../lib/libosgEarthFeatures.dll -Wl,--out-implib,../../lib/libosgEarthFeatures.dll.a -Wl,--major-image-version,2,--minor-image-version,10 -Wl,--whole-archive CMakeFiles/osgEarthFeatures.dir/objects.a -Wl,--no-whole-archive @CMakeFiles/osgEarthFeatures.dir/linklibs.rsp
[  623s] /usr/lib64/gcc/i686-w64-mingw32/8.2.0/../../../../i686-w64-mingw32/bin/ld: CMakeFiles/osgEarthFeatures.dir/objects.a(FeatureMaskLayer.cpp.obj): in function `ZN8osgEarth13ShaderOptionsC4Ev':

[  623s] /usr/lib64/gcc/i686-w64-mingw32/8.2.0/../../../../i686-w64-mingw32/bin/ld: /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/osgearth-2.10.1/src/osgEarth/LayerShader:42: undefined reference to `osgEarth::ShaderOptions::fromConfig(osgEarth::Config const&)'

column13: Add CodeTriage badge to gwaldron/osgearth
column20:
Adds a badge showing the number of people helping this repo on CodeTriage.

What is CodeTriage?
CodeTriage is an Open Source app that is designed to make contributing to Open Source projects easier. It works by sending subscribers a few open issues in their inbox. If subscribers get busy, there is an algorithm that backs off issue load so they do not get overwhelmed
Read more about the CodeTriage project.
Why am I getting this PR?
Your project was picked by the human, @schneems. They selected it from the projects submitted to https://www.codetriage.com and hand edited the PR. How did your project get added to CodeTriage? Roughly over 3 years ago, lobocode added this project to CodeTriage in order to start contributing. Since then, 12 people have subscribed to help this repo.
What does adding a badge accomplish?
Adding a badge invites people to help contribute to your project. It also lets developers know that others are invested in the longterm success and maintainability of the project.
You can see an example of a CodeTriage badge on these popular OSS READMEs:

 https://github.com/rails/rails
 https://github.com/crystal-lang/crystal

Have a question or comment?
While I am a bot, this PR was manually reviewed and monitored by a human - @schneems. My job is writing commit messages and handling PR logistics.
If you have any questions, you can reply back to this PR and they will be answered by @schneems. If you do not want a badge right now, no worries, close the PR, you will not hear from me again.
Thanks for making your project Open Source! Any feedback is greatly appreciated.

column13: Add bar to show statistics data as label
WMS 1.3.0 bug fixes
column20: Fix inheritance of BoundingBox in WMS layers.  Also swap x and y coordinates for URIs for WMS when version is 1.3.0 or greater and using a geodetic profile since WMS 1.3.0 defines that x and y match the coordinate system standards instead of the 1.1.1 notation of long/lat.  Also add function to future proof version checks.  Solves integration issues with a third party WMS server.
column21: Fix inheritance of BoundingBox in WMS layers.  Also swap x and y coordinates for URIs for WMS when version is 1.3.0 or greater and using a geodetic profile since WMS 1.3.0 defines that x and y match the coordinate system standards instead of the 1.1.1 notation of long/lat.  Also add function to future proof version checks.  Solves integration issues with a third party WMS server.

column13: Triton: Turn off UBO if Mesa driver detected to prevent GL errors.
column20:
While testing on Linux, I'm getting a constant stream of errors on console when using Triton.  I traced it down to Unified Buffer Objects (UBO) using apitrace and MESA_DEBUG flag.  The UBO is on by default in latest Triton.config file (not sure about previous values).  Once I turned it off, the osgEarth and SIMDIS SDK Triton demos both worked well.
Note -- It might be advantageous to expose an interface to set individual Configuration settings both for Triton (and SilverLining for that matter) by creating a new field in TritonOptions.  I did not go that far with this approach.  I also did not attempt to fix this in Triton code directly because presumably eventually Mesa drivers might support UBO, and Triton already has a method for configuring this (Triton.config, Environment.SetConfigOption).
Testing was only done on Linux side with latest master of osgEarth and latest Triton.  Testing was done in osgearth_triton, example_ocean in SIMDIS SDK, and in SIMDIS itself.

column21:
Disregard this PR; during testing I apparently still had my Triton.config file set to "no" for this option.  Upon rebuild of everything I noticed this did not have desired effect.
Turns out this is read by the configuration from the Triton.config in Environment's initialize(), overriding any value you set here, then immediately used before control is returned to the user.  The only solutions that would work are:

Edit the Triton.config manually ahead of time
Override a method in ResourceLoader to force the value immediately after resource file loaded (messy)

There's not a good solution on osgEarth side of the fence.

column13: HTTPClient: Store impl as ref_ptr to avoid copy constructor crash on …
column20:
…gcc.
The crash happens because PerThread stores HTTPClient in a std::map, and in older C++ standard without emplace, that causes a copy constructor.  The copy constructor for HTTPClient is not implemented, so you get a double delete on _impl.  This change makes it a ref_ptr, fixing the double delete issue.  This does not impact MSVC presumably because it uses the emplace automatically, moving without invoking copy constructor.
column21:
…gcc.
The crash happens because PerThread stores HTTPClient in a std::map, and in older C++ standard without emplace, that causes a copy constructor.  The copy constructor for HTTPClient is not implemented, so you get a double delete on _impl.  This change makes it a ref_ptr, fixing the double delete issue.  This does not impact MSVC presumably because it uses the emplace automatically, moving without invoking copy constructor.

column21: setlocale is not thread-safe; in fact it is a per-process function that will affect all running threads. Is there some reason you cannot just call setlocale at application start?

column13: bugfix: incorrect WMS URI when using wrong locale
column20:
I have integrated the changes of podsvirov as discussed in #835 (comment).
I have tested it on a machine with a german locale. Before the fix, decimal numbers of the BBX were written with a ','. After fix the URI is created with a '.' in the decimal numbers.
column21: I understand that it is not thread-safe. However, we are developing applications in german and want to use the appropriate locale for display (e.g. have ',' as decimal separator) but when accessing WMS it requires '.' to be the decimal separator. Hence, it is not possible to set the locale for the whole application. Is there another option to fix this bug?

column13: PointDrawable: New insert() method.
column20: Unlike LineDrawable, PointDrawable::insert() is pretty simple to support.  We insert points into an ordered vector for code that we use that currently uses GL_POINTS, that we're trying to upgrade to PointDrawable.  Having access to an insert() method helps us avoid accessing the internals of PointDrawable directly to get done what we need to do.
column21: Unlike LineDrawable, PointDrawable::insert() is pretty simple to support.  We insert points into an ordered vector for code that we use that currently uses GL_POINTS, that we're trying to upgrade to PointDrawable.  Having access to an insert() method helps us avoid accessing the internals of PointDrawable directly to get done what we need to do.

column13: KML_Geometry parseCoords ensures all coords are parsed in case of a comment within the coord list
column20: If a comment is found while parsing the coordinate list in the rapidxml.hpp, the coords found after the comment are all added as another child node, but the m_value field string only reflects the first node. Instead, iterate through all of the coordinate node's child nodes to make sure all coordinates are parsed.

column13: Moved PrimiveIntersector::Intersection copy constructor
column20:
The copy constructor for PrimitiveIntersector::Intersection was defined in
the cpp file while the rest of the struct was defined inline in the
header.  This meant that you couldn't copy the struct without from your
own project without getting linker errors.  I simply moved the copy ctor
to be inline like the rest of the struct.

column13: Fix osg::Observer usage.  Removed Observer from AnnotationNode, fixed…
column20: … iterator invalidation from GeoTransform.
column21: … iterator invalidation from GeoTransform.

column13: Fix osg::Observer usage.  Removed Observer from AnnotationNode, fixed…
column20: … iterator invalidation from GeoTransform.
column21:
The issue is that the values where Observer were attached were already in an observer_ptr.  In AnnotationNode's case, there's no benefit that I can see to having it be an Observer, because the set-to-NULL operation in the callback is already happening anyways, and nothing "extra" happens.
In the case of GeoTransform, extra stuff is happening on delete.  There are two problems with the objectDeleted implementation here though:

There's a comparison against the observer_ptr in the first line.  But that observer_ptr might (or might not) have gotten its objectDeleted call, and may already be NULL.  So it's not a great idea to do the comparison here because it might erroneously fail due to order of operations in OSG C++ code.  To fix, we don't compare, since it's only called when the object being observed is deleted and we can only ever observe the item that is _terrain.  So the check is superfluous.  I added checks to setTerrain() to make sure the checks in objectDeleted are superfluous.
Setting the observer_ptr to NULL will cause it to remove itself from a list of Observers that is currently being iterated.  This leads to iterator invalidation.  Instead, don't touch _terrain and let observer_ptr do its job, preventing iterator invalidation, which led to crashes.

column13: CentOS compile error fix for PRIu64 macro
column20:
Tested on CentOS 6.10, using gcc 8.3.1.  Also confirmed build on MSVC 2019 x64.
This fixes failures in ImageLayer.cpp and ElevationLayer.cpp introduced near e1cb5c7e195b5 with a swap to use the macro PRIu64.  Some compilers won't respect the macro without defining __STDC_FORMAT_MACROS prior to includes of inttypes.h (or cinttypes).
Another possible solution is to #define this macro only in the .cpp files that require it, at the top of the file prior to other includes.  Another possible solution is to replace PRIu64 with something like "%llu" and hope for the best.  I thought this CMake solution was cleanest.
column21:
Tested on CentOS 6.10, using gcc 8.3.1.  Also confirmed build on MSVC 2019 x64.
This fixes failures in ImageLayer.cpp and ElevationLayer.cpp introduced near e1cb5c7e195b5 with a swap to use the macro PRIu64.  Some compilers won't respect the macro without defining __STDC_FORMAT_MACROS prior to includes of inttypes.h (or cinttypes).
Another possible solution is to #define this macro only in the .cpp files that require it, at the top of the file prior to other includes.  Another possible solution is to replace PRIu64 with something like "%llu" and hope for the best.  I thought this CMake solution was cleanest.

column13: Threading: Add missing <functional> header for MSVC 2019/gcc.
Threading: Mark Mutex assignment and copy operators as deleted to avo…
column20:
…id erronous mutex copies.  Add WorkingSet::clear() as a way to invalidate the cache.
If a Mutex instance is copied, I see a crash on exit.  Marking the copy operators as deleted will prevent this while compiling.
The WorkingSet needs a way to invalidate its cache.  Previously we had been using a copy constructor to do this.  This led to the Mutex being copied, which led to the crash.  Now that the Mutex cannot be copied, there needs to be a way to invalidate the cache in the WorkingSet, hence the new clear() method.
column21:
…id erronous mutex copies.  Add WorkingSet::clear() as a way to invalidate the cache.
If a Mutex instance is copied, I see a crash on exit.  Marking the copy operators as deleted will prevent this while compiling.
The WorkingSet needs a way to invalidate its cache.  Previously we had been using a copy constructor to do this.  This led to the Mutex being copied, which led to the crash.  Now that the Mutex cannot be copied, there needs to be a way to invalidate the cache in the WorkingSet, hence the new clear() method.

column13: Threading: SetThreadName now checks _WIN32_WINNT target version. Adds…
column20: … path to support Win7 again.
column21: … path to support Win7 again.

column13: Threading: SetThreadName now checks _WIN32_WINNT target version. Adds…
column20: … path to support Win7 again.
column21:
Some more details beyond the commit message:
We are building osgEarth on MSVC 2019, which has a newer Windows SDK by default than some of the older MSVC versions.  As such, the Win10 preprocessor define is defined.  I can, on a Windows 7 (I know) machine build the software, but then can't run it on the same machine.
Adding this check by itself does not cause the code to work, because if undefined, _WIN32_WINNT will default to _WIN32_WINNT_WIN10.  But this gives us an opportunity to set the target _WIN32_WINNT in our CMake configuration, allowing us to target older versions than Windows 10.
Without this change (and a define in CMake command line / CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS), osgEarth builds on MSVC 2019 in such a way that it will only run on Windows 10 systems.  With this change, that's still the same default, but you can specify CXX flags to override that behavior.

column13: FileUtils: getTempName() adds thread ID, making it more robust while threading
column20: I am using GDALDEM driver, which is getting lots of errors on the console about various TIF files already existing or not existing.  This has led to crashes at runtime.  This change works around that problem by encoding the thread ID into the temporary filename, which helps prevent multi-threaded failures.  As a result, GDALDEM no longer crashes sporadically and I haven't seen any filename errors yet.

column13: GDALDEM: Clean-up, fix missing functions, add alpha option, rename altitude to lightAltitude.
column20:
Have been using GDALDEM and ran into several issues that this PR fixes:

altitude option and text appears to be taken already by ImageLayer::Options::altitude().  Renamed to get/setLightAltitude() (light_altitude) in order to not hide the base class value
Added 'alpha' option, which is useful on color-relief images
Added various documentation on the options, since many were not obvious in their intent or usage
Setting the elevation layer now reopens the layer if needed
Added implementation for various get/set functions, which were declared but not implemented.
Fixed return values on getMultidirectional() and getCombined()

column13: ElevationPool: Fix overflow error in getSample().
column20:
ElevationPool::getSample() provides a signature that omits the maximum LOD parameter.  In this case, it is fed in as ~0, which is of type unsigned.  This function gets it, and on old line 761 typecasts it to an int so that osg::minimum() can be used.  But that typecast results in a negative number, making lod always be -1 when coming from that other signature.
This fixes that problem by limiting the incoming maxLOD value to, at most, std::numeric_limits<int>::max().
column21:
ElevationPool::getSample() provides a signature that omits the maximum LOD parameter.  In this case, it is fed in as ~0, which is of type unsigned.  This function gets it, and on old line 761 typecasts it to an int so that osg::minimum() can be used.  But that typecast results in a negative number, making lod always be -1 when coming from that other signature.
This fixes that problem by limiting the incoming maxLOD value to, at most, std::numeric_limits<int>::max().
