column13: Added setting of VertexArrayState VBO usage flag to ensure VBO is bound if necessary
column20: Added setting of VBO usage flag in VertexArrayState prior to drawing in SharedGeometry::drawImplementation() because sometimes (at least on Windows) the OSG StatsHandler would change this VBO usage flag to false prior to SharedGeometry::drawImplementation() being called.  This would cause the VBO to not be bound when glDrawElements was called and resulted in crashes.
column21: Added setting of VBO usage flag in VertexArrayState prior to drawing in SharedGeometry::drawImplementation() because sometimes (at least on Windows) the OSG StatsHandler would change this VBO usage flag to false prior to SharedGeometry::drawImplementation() being called.  This would cause the VBO to not be bound when glDrawElements was called and resulted in crashes.

column13: Added setting of VertexArrayState VBO usage flag to ensure VBO is bound if necessary
column20: Added setting of VBO usage flag in VertexArrayState prior to drawing in SharedGeometry::drawImplementation() because sometimes (at least on Windows) the OSG StatsHandler would change this VBO usage flag to false prior to SharedGeometry::drawImplementation() being called.  This would cause the VBO to not be bound when glDrawElements was called and resulted in crashes.
column21: Thanks Jeff!

column13: TerrainEngineNode: Reset the tile mode factory when shutting down.
column20:
On start-up I am creating a new map node and putting it into the scene.  The old map node is being destroyed.  The old map node's Tile Model Factory is still active at this time.  It is crashing because of an access to a stale reference to the terrain options.  Tile Model Factory references a terrain options that is owned by the MapNode.  So when the MapNode gets destroyed, the Tile Model Factory should also stop processing in order to avoid holding a stale reference to the MapNode terrain options.
This change does that by leveraging the already-existing shutdown() method to drop the ref_ptr _tileModelFactory.
There's a minor change in the Rex engine that also makes sure the derived version of the function calls the parent version.
column21:
On start-up I am creating a new map node and putting it into the scene.  The old map node is being destroyed.  The old map node's Tile Model Factory is still active at this time.  It is crashing because of an access to a stale reference to the terrain options.  Tile Model Factory references a terrain options that is owned by the MapNode.  So when the MapNode gets destroyed, the Tile Model Factory should also stop processing in order to avoid holding a stale reference to the MapNode terrain options.
This change does that by leveraging the already-existing shutdown() method to drop the ref_ptr _tileModelFactory.
There's a minor change in the Rex engine that also makes sure the derived version of the function calls the parent version.

column13: fix 3dtiles refine bug
column20:
I found that if the Tile corresponding to ThreeDTileNode does not have a refine member, osgEarth cannot handle the refine method correctly.
If the Tile corresponding to ThreeDTileNode does not have a refine member, according to the 3dtiles specification, we should inherit the refine method of the parent Tile, and this process should be at the beginning of the ThreeDTileNode, instead of inheriting the refine method of the parent Tile after the construction is completed, because at this time The refine of the inherited parent Tile is likely to be REFINE_ADD initialized by default.

column13: fix 3dtiles refine bug
column20:
I found that if the Tile corresponding to ThreeDTileNode does not have a refine member, osgEarth cannot handle the refine method correctly.
If the Tile corresponding to ThreeDTileNode does not have a refine member, according to the 3dtiles specification, we should inherit the refine method of the parent Tile, and this process should be at the beginning of the ThreeDTileNode, instead of inheriting the refine method of the parent Tile after the construction is completed, because at this time The refine of the inherited parent Tile is likely to be REFINE_ADD initialized by default.
column21: Since the refine of Tile is inherited from the parent Tile, we need to traverse down from the root Tile to get the correct refine of the Tile. If the parent Tile is not initialized in the constructor of ThreeDTileNode, the refine inheritance of setParentTile to Tile will be From the leaf node to the root node, this will get the wrong refine, unless we traverse twice, the first time from the root tile down to initialize ThreeDTileNode, the second time from the root tile down to set up refine. do you mean this?

If you remove the initialization if the _refine then it will be under, so when setParentTile is called the node should inherit the refine of it's direct parent, which should have been either set explicitly in the tileset.json or inherited by it's parent.
Do you have a 3d tiles dataset that shows the issue and I can look into it here?

column13: Deleting duplicate line.
Earth Serializer: Apply relative path now also to fields containing underscores
column20:
For example, field names uri and url were converted for relative path, but field names like texture_uri and cursor_url were not converted.  This led to saved earth files not being able to be loaded properly in some conditions.
This change basically expands the definition of which fields will be processed for URL handling for rewriting paths as relative, so more field names will be included.

column13: 3.1: github actions for windows, linux and macos
column20:
Add github actions to build osgEarth 3.1 on windows, linux and macos. "vcpkg" only works with windows. using xcode 12 on macos. I've tested it on my osgEarth 3.1 branch. All builds successed, but one need to test/adapt it for osgEarth repository.
All action have "workflow_dispatch". To build it on push, one can change this to "push".
Attention: The "windows action" use "vcpkg" and creates "nuget" packages on your current github account!

column13: JobArena: Add queueSize() public method.
column20: Using this in a client application to determine if there are asynchronous jobs running for the terrain paging.  Previously we were relying on output from the Registry's activities, but asynchronous layers don't show up there.  The easy solution for us was to query both the Registry activities, and to also query whether there are queued async jobs.  Combined, this looks good on our end user app.
column21: Using this in a client application to determine if there are asynchronous jobs running for the terrain paging. The easy solution for us was to query both the Registry activities, and to also query whether there are queued async jobs.  Combined, this looks good on our end user app.

column13: WMS: Avoid nullptr dereference on wms_srs.  Avoid soft assert on Profile::create() with nullptr srs
column20:
Was getting a crash with a WMS server that reported ESPG:26915 SRS, and my system returns nullptr when trying to create.  This patch avoids a nullptr dereference on wms_srs in the lower portion, that was crashing the application.
Afterwards I was still getting a soft assert in Profile::create() due to the null SRS.  I protected against that too.
column21:

Afterwards I was still getting a soft assert in Profile::create() due to the null SRS.  I protected against that too.

column13: Change webp -> libwebp in build.md
column20:
The instructions say to install the optional dependency webp:x64-windows which throws the error:
Error: while loading web:
The port directory (C:\src\vcpkg\ports\webp) does not exist
Error: failed to load port from C:\src\vcpkg\ports\webp
Note: Updating vcpkg by rerunning bootstrap-vcpkg may resolve this failure.

Changing the package name to libwebp:x64-windows removes the error.  Was the package name changed recently?  I'm not certain that this is the correct fix, so someone in-the-know should verify that it is.

column13: Registry: Revert 957f487d change, now registry ref_ptr is global inst…
column20:
…ead of local to instance().
Fixes order of destruction issue when using e.g. ImageOverlay, where _program destruction happens after ~Registry, and ImageOverlay's VirtualProgram accesses a stale ProgramRepo reference, leading to a crash.
column21:
…ead of local to instance().
Fixes order of destruction issue when using e.g. ImageOverlay, where _program destruction happens after ~Registry, and ImageOverlay's VirtualProgram accesses a stale ProgramRepo reference, leading to a crash.

column13: Registry: Revert 957f487d change, now registry ref_ptr is global inst…
column20:
…ead of local to instance().
Fixes order of destruction issue when using e.g. ImageOverlay, where _program destruction happens after ~Registry, and ImageOverlay's VirtualProgram accesses a stale ProgramRepo reference, leading to a crash.
column21:
This is not a perfect fix.  It works around the problem by not allowing instance() to return a stale pointer.  This prevents crash on exit.  My use case is a standalone application running a test where the application creates an ImageOverlay instance.  Its static _program gets destroyed after the Registry is destroyed, which leads to the crash I'm seeing.
The crash was introduced in 957f487, but we didn't update past that revision internally until yesterday.  Sorry for noticing the problem late.

column13: Threading: Initialize atomic<int> values to 0 in constructor.
column20: On MSVC 2019 and release mode MSVC 2017, the atomic<int> was initializing to 0 as the code expects already.  But on debug MSVC 2017, I was seeing random values.  This meant that the metrics were not starting at 0, and therefore not useful.  This fixes that problem.
column21: On MSVC 2019 and release mode MSVC 2017, the atomic<int> was initializing to 0 as the code expects already.  But on debug MSVC 2017, I was seeing random values.  This meant that the metrics were not starting at 0, and therefore not useful.  This fixes that problem.

column13: Rex SharedGeometry: Refactor draw primitives implementation to fix ATI rendering issues with older drivers.
column21:
@remoe We have been getting reports for the last several months from users who can no longer view the globe. These were all users with older cards (e.g. Matrox C420 with 22.19.693.256 driver, AMD Radeon HD 7730M) that were experiencing this issue. Drivers were as upgraded as they could get (newer drivers don't support older card).
The symptom manifested essentially as a blank, black globe. With the simple sky model enabled, we could see the lighting along the edge of the globe, but no texture data. We could add things like line features onto the globe and they were drawn correctly, it was just the underlying globe imagery data that wasn't rendering. This used to work on software releases 9+ months back.
We were able to generate API Trace output from a failing laptop. When running the replay through API Trace, the display was incorrect when run on the AMD Radeon HD 7730M. But when we ran the exact same trace file through API Trace on systems with other cards, everything was looking fine.
Current belief is that there's something funky with the VAO state and EBO that isn't being captured by these older cards, forcing a requirement to generate and rebind it each time.

column13: LineDrawable: Fix data variance on contained geometry.
column20:
We have seen issues in our code where lines are no longer updating properly after the 7/15 update in 0be4fb979
We thought we were missing calls to dirty(), but I investigated today when we encountered similar issues with lines drawn from the Callouts technique in screen space layout code. I found the underlying issue in a missing data variance on the geometry.
After this change, callout lines updated properly. I suspect this fixes all of our various line drawable issues.

column13: WMS: Change structure to a set to avoid an O(n^2) SRS lookup loop.
column20: I have a WMS server that I'm connecting to that has over 6000 reported supported SRS in a parent layer, with more than 600 layers under it. I'm seeing a 30 second delay to load the layer due to SRS processing. This change reduces the load time by an order of magnitude by eliminating an n^2 loop that was preventing duplicate entries. std::set now forces uniqueness.

column13: MBTiles: Close database on destruction, fixing leak and #1738
column20:
We found a leak when loading multiple .earth files in a row in the range of several megabytes. Tracked it down to missing sqlite_close statement. #1738 appears to be the same issue.
After implementing this, I was able to move files on disk after the terrain closed out, and I was seeing much less memory growth over time when repeatedly loading .earth files at runtime.

column13: ScreenSpaceLayout: Enable state now correctly updates for callouts, w…
column20: …hen text priority or declutter state changes while label is valid but not drawn.
column21:
We have a report where a LabelNode is incorrectly showing the callout for the screen space layout, when the user thought the declutter was disabled for this particular label (via TextSymbol::declutter() and via LabelNode->setPriority()).
I was finally able to reproduce the bad behavior by rendering the label, seeing the callout, then changing our scenario such that the label is not visible. For our time-based application, this simply meant looping time around to before the entity creation. The label was still valid, just not visible. At this time, the priority and declutter flags update (verified with cout). And simultaneously, the label is turned back on.
I was able to fix this by checking the fields in the layoutData more regularly, allowing them to turn on or off the Element::_declutter flag dynamically. After this change I no longer see bad behavior on my end.

column13: Rework Threading internal queue
column20:
This commit rework Threading internal queue

It replaces the vector + partial sorting with a std::priority_queue
In introduces a proper abstraction for the internal queue of job
SynchronizedPriorityQueuedJob. By doing so,

it removes a datarace that was happening on _done
it ensures that the variables used in the condition_variable
are always modified while holding the lock, preventing improper use
of block with predicate (as there is small window between the predicate
call and the lock which cam lead to lost notifications)


It refactors the code with this new SynchronizedPriorityQueuedJob.

column13: TileNode: Fix naked pointer that can be dereferenced after deletion during UnloaderGroup dormant tile collection.
column20:
Basically, during an update traversal, UnloaderGroup is going through its dead pool, after collecting dormant tiles. As it looks through the dead pool, it pulls out a tile’s parent. This is a naked pointer inside the TileNode. The parent appears to have been deleted already. Several fields are 0xdddddddd. The tile itself seems OK and valid, it’s just the parent tile that appears invalid.
I have not had success reproducing this in osgEarth examples. The crash happens during the update traversal through UnloaderGroup.

column13: ImageUtils::ColorWriter float/double mixup
column20: Fix for issues found stemming from f551c75. GLTypeTraits<>::scale() all return double. Float conversion issues are causing artifacts near edges, preventing some pixel-testing from working, which we use for transparent image guessing.
column21: Fix for issues found stemming from f551c75. GLTypeTraits<>::scale() all return double. Float conversion issues are causing artifacts near edges, preventing some pixel-testing from working, which we use for transparent image guessing.

column13: ImageUtils::ColorWriter float/double mixup
column20: Fix for issues found stemming from f551c75. GLTypeTraits<>::scale() all return double. Float conversion issues are causing artifacts near edges, preventing some pixel-testing from working, which we use for transparent image guessing.
column21: I'm surprised this is an issue, especially only on writing as I see the read is still using floats.  Can you give an example of what kind of issues you're seeing or provide a bit of example code showing the issue?

column13: ImageUtils::ColorWriter float/double mixup
column20: Fix for issues found stemming from f551c75. GLTypeTraits<>::scale() all return double. Float conversion issues are causing artifacts near edges, preventing some pixel-testing from working, which we use for transparent image guessing.
column21:
I think it's only an issue on writing because the ColorReaders cast the results of the pointer increments to float before performing an operation, whereas the ColorWriters don't.
As an example, the image we're sending through this code via osgEarth::ImageUtils::convertToRGBA8() is white .bmp image with a small blue arrow in the middle. We convert it to RGBA format, then run a transparent color guess algorithm on the image (adapted from FOX code) to determine what color we should be replacing with transparent.
Before the change in the commit referenced above, ColorWriter for GL_RGBA correctly converted the pixels to 255. After the change, the RGBA values are 254.
The image resulting from osgEarth::ImageUtils::convertToRGBA8() returns true from osg::Image::isImageTranslucent(), when it didn't before, which we use as an early-out on our own code when guessing a color to replace with transparent. Hope this all makes sense.

column13: ImageUtils::ColorWriter float/double mixup
column20: Fix for issues found stemming from f551c75. GLTypeTraits<>::scale() all return double. Float conversion issues are causing artifacts near edges, preventing some pixel-testing from working, which we use for transparent image guessing.
column21: Thanks for the explanation, makes sense to me and thanks for the fix!
